ranked_diseases.explanation: Most common genetic cause of CKD in adults, typically manifests in 4th-5th decade. Progressive cyst formation leads to ESRD by age 50-60 in many patients.
Less likely given typical childhood onset, but late presentations have been reported. Can progress to ESRD in adulthood in milder cases.
Progressive hereditary nephritis that can lead to ESRD by middle age, particularly in males. Would typically have other features like hearing loss.
Adult form can present with ESRD in 4th-5th decade. Characterized by tubular basement membrane disruption and tubulointerstitial fibrosis.
Genetic form of FSGS can progress to ESRD in adulthood. Age of presentation varies widely depending on genetic variant.
Most common primary glomerulonephritis worldwide. Can progress to ESRD over 20-30 years from onset, fitting with patient's age.
Autosomal dominant tubulointerstitial kidney disease that typically leads to ESRD between ages 40-60.
X-linked lysosomal storage disorder. Males can develop progressive kidney disease leading to ESRD by 4th-5th decade.
